snippet: In all three countries, mass killings have had a mobilizing effect and resulted in changes to laws and regulations.
abstract: Pres Obama has angrily pointed out differences between America and its allies in responding to gun violence; mass shootings in Australia, Britain and Canada have resulted in rapid changes to laws and regulations, while incidents like shooting in Roseburg, Ore, have left America mired in legislative stalemates that some blame on power of pro-gun lobbying group National Rifle Assn.

byline.original: By DAN BILEFSKY, AUSTIN RAMZY and IAN AUSTEN
byline.contributor: Dan Bilefsky reported from London, and Austin Ramzy from Hong Kong.

lead_paragraph: In all three countries, mass killings have had a mobilizing effect and resulted in changes to laws and regulations.

headline.main: How Australia, Britain and Canada Have Responded to Gun Violence
headline.print_headline: Rampages in Australia, Britain and Canada Prompted Steps to Regulate Weapons
